item.title: Bristol protest: Police attacked as 'Kill the Bill' demo turns violent
item.description: Officers suffer broken bones in scenes the home secretary calls "unacceptable".

item.title: Fireworks thrown in 'unprecedented' Bristol violence
item.description: "This is the worst violence in Bristol for many, many years," the Police Federation says.

item.title: Defence review: Army 'to be reduced by 10,000 troops'
item.description: A review of the UK's defence policy sees new investment in cyber warfare, robotics and drones.

item.title: Australia floods: Thousands evacuated as downpours worsen
item.description: Sydney and other cities are braced for more downpours amid the region's worst flooding in decades.

item.title: Donald Trump plans social media comeback, says adviser
item.description: The ex-US president, banned by Twitter and Facebook, will launch "his own platform", an aide says.

item.title: Covid: Supermarket limits lifted as lockdown in Wales eases
item.description: Supermarkets can sell non-essential items and garden centres can open from Monday.

item.title: Covid survivor Scott Howell thanks hospital staff for saving his life
item.description: A year after being put on a ventilator, Scott Howell returned to the hospital where he was treated.

item.title: Brazil president rails against lockdown 'tyrants'
item.description: The Brazilian president says it is now time to reopen the economy, despite a surge in infections.

item.title: Green plan to upgrade homes was 'botched', say MPs
item.description: A scheme offering people up to £10,000 for insulation has only reached 10% of its target, MPs say.

item.title: Covid-19: Miami Beach imposes emergency curfew over spring break 'chaos'
item.description: Large crowds on the US city's party strips prompted an emergency overnight curfew.

item.title: Old Firm fans praised for heeding 'stay at home' call
item.description: No arrests were made in following Sunday's Old Firm match and police thanked fans for respecting lockdown restrictions.

item.title: Israel election hopes and fears play out in crater town
item.description: For voters in Mitzpe Ramon, Tuesday's poll means keeping or casting out Israel's PM Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: Leicester City 3-1 Man Utd: Foxes into FA Cup semi-finals
item.description: Leicester City move into the FA Cup semi-finals for the first time since 1981-82 as they eliminate Manchester United at the King Power Stadium.

item.title: The Papers: 'Tussle' over Covid vaccines, and fiery protest pictures
item.description: Brussels' threat to ban AstraZeneca Covid vaccine exports to Britain dominates Monday's front pages.

item.title: Australia floods: Cows rescued from swollen rivers and beaches
item.description: Exhausted animals have been pulled from swollen rivers, beaches and flooded suburbs.

item.title: How can I stop my houseplants dying?
item.description: With houseplant sales booming, expert Giacomo Plazzotta offers tips for keeping them healthy.

item.title: Kitboga: How AI is helping me waste scammers’ time
item.description: Twitch streamer, Kitboga, says he wanted to stop con artists trying to steal from people.

item.title: Wingate arson: Ex-marine Sean Ivey 'overwhelmed' by generosity
item.description: A campaign raises over £200,000 for the family after a suspected arson attack destroyed their home.

item.title: Dog thefts: The woman who rescues stolen dogs
item.description: A woman who rescues stolen pets says the crime has "rocketed out of control" during lockdown.

item.title: The former fighters embracing peace in the Philippines Mindanao region
item.description: Former fighters are embracing peace in Mindanao in the Philippines, in the hope of ending decades of killing.

item.title: One Year On: A pandemic poem for Londoners
item.description: The writers behind All on the Board pay tribute to Londoners on the eve of the anniversary of the start of first lockdown.

item.title: Covid: NHS staff say change was the silver lining of the pandemic
item.description: The health service has seen drastic change, including video consultations and leaps in research.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid inequality: No vaccination for poverty in a pandemic
item.description: People on the financial precipice are disproportionately likely to be unemployed, renting, female, and black.

item.title: Why India is talking about ripped jeans and knees
item.description: Thousands of women are sharing their photos in ripped jeans on social media - but why?

item.title: 'I’ll buy five items and only keep one of them'
item.description: With online returns soaring during the pandemic, tech firms are helping retailers deal with the rise.

item.title: Coronavirus: Covid nurses' song of hope from Italy
item.description: Simona Camosci wrote the song in the first Covid wave, and now she and her colleagues have released it.

item.title: Coronavirus: Dying nurse told sister 'follow in my footsteps'
item.description: Areema Nasreen was one of the youngest NHS workers to die of Covid-19 at the start of the pandemic.

item.title: Egyptian feminist Nawal El Saadawi dies at 89
item.description: Nawal El Saadawi, who has died at 89, drew outrage and admiration in her conservative home country.

item.title: North Korea’s ‘only openly gay defector’ finds love
item.description: Jang Yeong-jin fled North Korea to escape a loveless marriage. Now he is engaged to his boyfriend.

item.title: 'It is sad we need bad defeat for this reaction' - Spurs bounce back to beat Villa
item.description: Tottenham respond to their shock Europa League exit with victory over Aston Villa to keep their hopes of a Premier League top-four finish alive.

item.title: BBC to show WSL games on network TV for first time in new 'landmark' deal
item.description: BBC will show live Women's Super League matches on network TV for the first time as part of a multi-million-pound broadcast deal with Sky Sports.

item.title: Messi celebrates record Barca appearance with two goals in thrashing of Sociedad
item.description: Lionel Messi scores two goals on his record-breaking 768th appearance for Barcelona as the Spanish giants beat Real Sociedad 6-1 in La Liga.

item.title: FA Cup: Leicester City 3-1 Manchester United highlights
item.description: Watch highlights as two goals from in-form Kelechi Iheanacho gives Leicester City a 3-1 win over Manchester United in the FA Cup quarter-finals.

item.title: FA Cup: Chelsea 2-0 Sheffield United highlights
item.description: Watch highlights as Hakim Ziyech's late strike seals Chelsea's place in the semi-finals at the expense of a battling Sheffield United.

item.title: FA Cup: Kelechi Iheanacho pounces on Fred's calamitous backpass to put Foxes in front
item.description: Kelechi Iheanacho latches on to Fred's wayward backpass as Manchester United concede a calamitous opening goal in their FA Cup quarter-final tie against Leicester City.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are the latest group to be invited to book their Covid vaccine.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The culture secretary has said they are looking at "covid certification" for attending large events

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 26 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: Shielding in England will end on 31 March.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Coronavirus: How are the rules for weddings changing across the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: The government says it may still be too early to book summer holidays abroad.

item.title: EU plans for a 'vaccine passport' to allow travel
item.description: 'Vaccine passport' plans have been proposed by the EU, in order to make travel easier this summer.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: Coronavirus: Data by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: Phone scammers: 'Give me £1,000 to stop calling you'
item.description: The rise of scam calls seems relentless - but can anything be done about them?

item.title: So you want a career in building computer games?
item.description: A career in computer games can be rewarding but tough to get into.

item.title: Bedfordshire: Army officer restores WW2 'secret garden' at Chicksands Priory
item.description: The garden at Chicksands Priory was used by code-breakers in World War Two but had been neglected.

item.title: Jed Mercurio: Line of Duty 'still in post-production'
item.description: Line of Duty writer Jed Mercurio says the new series is still not ready, despite airing on Sunday.

item.title: Covid: Lack of contraception sees goats boom in Llandudno
item.description: The Great Orme's goats have not been given their usual contraceptive injection due to the pandemic.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.
